title: 108_hr5375
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations Accountability Act of 2004". The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption. OIOS audits revealed mismanagement in contracts for inspection services in Iraq. The United Nations contracted inspection services in Iraq were found to be inadequately managed, with staffing levels not met and overcharging of the United Nations. The OIOS audit found that the contractor did not adhere to certain provisions of the contract, including failing to maintain required staffing levels, overcharging the United Nations, engaging in unprofessional conduct, and reporting inaccurate figures for goods. The audit also highlighted the need for the United Nations Office of Iraq Programs to improve contract management and designate a manager in Iraq. The OIOS audit found that the United Nations Office of Iraq Programs needed to improve contract management by designating a manager in Iraq to ensure services were in line with contracts. The United Nations policy is not to release OIOS audit reports to member states. The United States was denied access to the reports. The United Nations policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states has hindered the United States' access to audits of the Oil-for-Food Program, despite repeated requests. This policy undermines member states' ability to fulfill their responsibilities in connection with UN programs. The United Nations policy of not releasing OIOS audit reports to member states hinders their ability to fulfill responsibilities in connection with UN programs. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. Congress urges the President to ensure that all OIOS audit reports are promptly shared with UN member states without modifications, except to protect privacy rights. The Department of State must report on UN officials' financial disclosure requirements within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The Department of State must assess financial disclosure rules for United Nations officials and recommend reforms within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines the terms "oil-for-food program" and "Office of Internal Oversight Services" in relation to United Nations resolutions. The curr_chunk defines the term "Office of Internal Oversight Services" as the UN office established to assist the Secretary General in internal oversight responsibilities. The curr_chunk defines "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate.
